results.title: Michael Gandolfini and the Riddle of Tony Soprano
results.abstract: In “The Many Saints of Newark,” James Gandolfini’s son takes on his father’s iconic role. But knowing his dad hardly prepared him for the work ahead.

multimedia.caption: Michael Gandolfini in New York. He pursued acting not because of his father but because he was “craving an answer” about whether he’d be good at it.

results.title: Roger Michell, Director of ‘Notting Hill,’ Is Dead at 65
results.abstract: He was an accomplished theater director as well as a filmmaker. But he was best known for his blockbuster romantic comedy starring Julia Roberts and Hugh Grant.

multimedia.caption: The director Roger Michell on the set of his film “Enduring Love” in 2004. “I have strong views about the kind of work I want to do,” he once said. “That’s all that guides me.”

results.title: Jim Jarmusch’s Collages Are Ready for Their Close-Up
results.abstract: The filmmaker has been quietly making small, eerie collages on newsprint for 20 years, with faces switched onto other bodies. Now they’re finally on view.

multimedia.caption: Jim Jarmusch likes removing heads in his tiny collages with newsprint. He’s been making them for 20 years and mostly keeping them to himself —  until now.

results.title: How Lip-Syncing Got Real
results.abstract: Not long ago, lip-syncing was the domain of subversive drag queens, or pop stars that the media saw as talentless. Now it’s how scrappy amateurs get famous.

results.title: 14 Cuts in 25 Minutes: How Hong Kong Censors Movies
results.abstract: The Asian film capital has cracked down on documentaries and independent productions that it fears could glamorize the pro-democracy movement.

results.title: Camille Cottin, de ‘Dix pour cent’ à Hollywood
results.abstract: Après le succès fulgurant de la série aux USA, la comédienne joue avec Matt Damon dans “Stillwater”, de Tom McCarthy. “Vous ne pouvez quasiment pas la quitter des yeux quand elle est à l’écran,” dit le réalisateur.

multimedia.caption: “Vous me dites que pendant la pandémie, tout le monde regardait “Call My Agent !” J’étais à mille lieues de ça, au contraire, je me sentais enterrée vivante,” dit Camille Cottin.
multimedia.copyright: Tania Franco Klein pour The New York Times

results.title: ‘Stillwater’, l’autre tragédie américaine
results.abstract: Dans le dernier film de Tom McCarthy, le rôle tenu par Matt Damon est sur-travaillé, d’une réserve plombante. Mais l’électrique Camille Cottin donne de la force à son personnage et de la gravité à ses scènes.

results.title: Mo Abudu Isn’t Waiting for Permission
results.abstract: Known as “Africa’s answer to Oprah,” Abudu has built a media empire aimed at bringing Nigerian stories to the world. Her huge Netflix deal should help.
des_facet: The Secret Lives of Baba Segi's Wives (Book)

multimedia.caption: “Gone are the days whereby you can force-feed me only American content,” said Mo Abudu, whose company, EbonyLife Media, is behind many of Nigeria’s biggest films and TV shows.

results.title: Melvin Van Peebles, Champion of New Black Cinema, Dies at 89
results.abstract: A fertile creative force, he wrote fiction and musicals but is best known for a breakthrough movie that heralded the genre known as blaxploitation.
des_facet: The Story of a Three-Day Pass (Movie)
Ain't Supposed to Die a Natural Death (Play)

multimedia.caption: The filmmaker, author and actor Melvin Van Peebles in his apartment in Manhattan in 2010. In his work he spoke out of an “undeniable Black consciousness,” one critic wrote.

results.title: Saadi Yacef, ‘Battle of Algiers’ Catalyst and Actor, Dies at 93
results.abstract: At the center of the Algerian effort to throw off French rule, he re-created that role in Gillo Pontecorvo’s searing 1966 movie, based on a book by Mr. Yacef.

multimedia.caption: Saadi Yacef, second from left, in a scene from “The Battle of Algiers,” a movie by Gillo Pontecorvo about the war between Algerian independence fighters and France. Mr. Yacef had fought in the war, and his writings were the basis for the movie.

Saadi Yacef, second from left, in a scene from “The Battle of Algiers,” a movie by Gillo Pontecorvo about the war between Algerian independence fighters and France. Mr. Yacef had fought in the war, and his writings were the basis for the movie.

results.title: Lena Waithe, Gillian Flynn to Start Book Imprints
results.abstract: The two women are joining Zando, an independent publishing company founded last year that plans to work with authors and sell books in unconventional ways.

multimedia.caption: “I’m hoping we can have a force multiplier effect on books that would have sold modestly or wouldn’t have been a priority at a large publishing house,” said Molly Stern, Zando’s founder. “Now there will be air around them.”
multimedia.copyright: Gabriela Herman for The New York Times
